messageBody:
--- Kent Beck wrote:
> The existence of the Composite pattern in the
> Test/TestCase/TestSuite troika caused us problems.
> [...] One particularly vexing problem was re-running
> single tests while making sure all the TestDecorators
> and TestSuite subclasses higher in the test tree were
> run correctly.

Interesting. Seems to me like some IDE test runners particularly
like the Composite pattern -- so they can show the package tree of
the tests.

Could the Composite structure be used to simplify the "run one test"
scenario? If each run is a suite with a collection of tests, then
running them would be a depth-first visitation of the nodes:
1. Run the "run once before all tests" method of the suite.
2. Run all the tests of the suite.
3. Run the "run once after all tests" method.
Each test would also have its "before and after" calls -- setUp and
tearDown. To run one test, navigate up to the root, then run
every "start" method. Then run the test. Then run every tearDown
method, back up to the root.

* Embrace Composite *

;->
